title: Peter's Deliverance and Herod's Judgment
shortSummary: Acts 12 recounts the intense persecution of the early church under King Herod, including the martyrdom of James and the miraculous rescue of Peter from prison by an angel. The chapter concludes with Herod's prideful death and the continued growth of God's word through the ministry of Barnabas and Saul.
timeline: c. AD 44 - Early Church Persecution under Herod Agrippa I

keyCharacters.name: Herod Agrippa I
keyCharacters.description: King who persecuted the church, killed James, imprisoned Peter, and died suddenly after accepting divine judgment.

keyCharacters.name: Peter
keyCharacters.description: One of Jesus’ apostles who was imprisoned by Herod but miraculously delivered by an angel.

keyCharacters.name: James, brother of John
keyCharacters.description: One of the twelve apostles, martyred by Herod with the sword.

keyCharacters.name: Rhoda
keyCharacters.description: A servant girl who recognized Peter’s voice at the door but was initially not believed.

keyCharacters.name: Barnabas
keyCharacters.description: A prominent early church leader who, along with Saul, returned from Jerusalem after completing their ministry.

definitions.definition: A military unit consisting of four soldiers; Herod assigned four quaternions to guard Peter.
In this context, likely referring to the Jewish Passover festival, during which Peter’s trial was planned.
A divine messenger sent by God to intervene and deliver Peter from prison.
Metal restraints used to bind prisoners, symbolizing Peter’s captivity and the miraculous nature of his release.

outline.heading: Herod’s Persecution and Peter’s Imprisonment
outline.description: Herod Agrippa I aggressively persecutes the church, killing James and imprisoning Peter, while the church earnestly prays for Peter’s deliverance.

outline.heading: Peter’s Miraculous Escape
outline.description: An angel of the Lord miraculously frees Peter from prison, leading him safely past guards and prison gates, demonstrating God’s sovereign power over earthly authorities.

outline.heading: Peter’s Arrival and the Church’s Reaction
outline.description: Peter arrives at the house of Mary, where believers are gathered in prayer; initial disbelief turns to astonishment as Peter recounts his deliverance.

outline.heading: Herod’s Failure and Death
outline.description: Herod’s prideful acceptance of divine praise leads to his sudden and gruesome death by divine judgment, confirming the necessity of giving God glory.

outline.heading: The Word of God Grows and the Return of Barnabas and Saul
outline.description: Despite persecution, the gospel continues to spread, and Barnabas and Saul return from Jerusalem with John Mark, ready to continue their ministry.

application: Persist in prayer for those facing persecution or trials, trusting God’s power to deliver and sustain.
Recognize God’s sovereignty over human authorities and circumstances, remaining faithful even when imprisoned or oppressed.
Respond to God’s deliverance with worship and testimony, encouraging the faith community.
Avoid pride and give God all glory, remembering that He alone holds ultimate authority over life and death.

keyVerses.text: Peter therefore was kept in prison: but prayer was made without ceasing of the church unto God for him.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the vital role of persistent prayer in the life of the church during times of crisis.

keyVerses.text: And, behold, the angel of the Lord came upon him, and a light shined in the prison: and he smote Peter on the side, and raised him up, saying, Arise up quickly. And his chains fell off from his hands.
keyVerses.significance: Demonstrates God's miraculous power to deliver His servants from impossible situations.

keyVerses.text: And immediately the angel of the Lord smote him, because he gave not God the glory: and he was eaten of worms, and gave up the ghost.
keyVerses.significance: A solemn warning against pride and failing to honor God as the ultimate authority.

keyVerses.text: But the word of God grew and multiplied.
keyVerses.significance: Affirms the unstoppable growth of the gospel despite opposition and persecution.
